sdgs.relevance:
SDG5: Harassmap. Born as a response to the persistent problem of sexual harassment on the streets of Egypt, to which society had become increasingly tolerant. It was the first independent initiative to work on this issue and was launched in December 2010 by a founding group of four women together with tech partners, advisers, and volunteers. It generated mass public dialogue, pushed the National Council for Women and several members of parliament to draft new laws, inspired a first successful court case, and encouraged women's NGOs who had previously been reluctant to take on this issue, to form an 18 member NGO Task Force on Sexual Harassment. In an independent review (https://www.ushahidi.com/in-action/towards-a-safer-city) of Harassmap.org, they concluded that the Ushahidi map is an effective tool for data collection for sensitive issues, encouraging more participation and sometimes more truthful reports than other typical data collection means. 
 
SDG6: Following the COVID pandemic, there was increased use of the Ushahidi platform globally by organizations and individuals self-organizing to provide mutual aid, document COVID-19 testing experiences, and create visibility on where to access essential resources for vulnerable communities. Ushahidi supported over 2000 deployments in over 140 countries. One such engagement was Humanitarian Open Street Maps (HOT) in Indonesia which set up a deployment to track and publicise handwashing stations across Indonesia to allow easier access for residents. The idea was inspired by early expert advice deeming handwashing as an effective way to prevent the spread of the virus. 
 
SDG13: Ushahidi was one of four organizations to win a Global Adaptation Index (GAIN) Prize in its inaugural year for its adaptation to urbanization, population growth, climate change and other global challenges (https://www.ushahidi.com/about/blog/ushahidi-wins-global-adaptation-index-prize). One such climate change deployment is the Hatfield Climate Resilience-MVP Plan which crowdsourced information about Hatfield and its climate resilience (https://mvp.ushahidi.io/views/map). A second example is the Tana River Climate Change & Livelihoods Restoration Project (https://tclirp.ushahidi.io/views/map) by World Vision Kenya that aimed to contribute to enabling environmental policy implementation, governance and environmental management through evidence generation using crowd geo-tagging. Case study report: https://www.gsma.com/mobilefordevelopment/resources/climate-change-adaptation-and-livelihood-restoration-in-tana-river-delta/?utm_source=LinkedIn&utm_medium=Social&utm_campaign=WVK
 
SDG 16: On good governance, Ushahidi was born out of an electoral crisis in Kenya. Ushahidi in practice can be read in the published paper titled “Crowdsourcing Accountability in a Nigerian Election” in the Journal of Information Technology & Politics by Catie Snow Bailard & Steven Livingston, proving that the use of Ushahidi – ReclaimNaija (http://www.reclaimnaija.net/)- increased voter turnout in the 2011 Nigerian election by 8%). Additionally,  Ushahidi has been used to monitor elections in India, Zambia, Mozambique, Nigeria, the USA and many other countries over the past decade. Our strategy has evolved from primarily reactionary to proactively engaging with ordinary citizens and stakeholders to help foster transparency and accountability in elections.  

The United Nations (UN) has a long history of working to maintain peace and security around the world. It strives to improve relations among nations and protect human rights. A second use case of SDG 16 is The UN Department of Field Services which used the Ushahidi platform for its peacekeeping operations. Called SAGE—Situational Awareness Geospatial Enterprise—the UN used the Ushahidi platform to collect, process and disseminate information from their field staff so the mission HQ has a better understanding of what’s happening on the ground, can triage accordingly, and can make better decisions.

Exporting Data from Ushahidi:
Ushahidi provides export functionality within the user interface using the platform APIs. This allows authorized users to export data from the platform and download the data as CSV file.

Importing Data into Ushahidi:
Ushahidi provides import functionality within the user interface using the platform APIs. This allows authorized users to import data into the platform as a CSV file. During this process, users are prompted to select the specific survey they wish to import the data into and map the columns of the CSV file to the corresponding survey fields.

https://docs.ushahidi.com/platform-developer-documentation/tech-stack/api-documentation#csv-exports-and-imports

userContent.contentManagementPolicy:
The responsibility for moderating and managing content ultimately rests with the organization or community using Ushahidi, while the platform provides mechanisms to address and deal with these issues.

Ushahidi allows for content moderation, meaning designated administrators or moderators can review incoming reports and data before they are published or made public. This moderation process helps identify and filter out any inappropriate or illegal content that violates community guidelines or legal requirements.

Ushahidi provides user management functionalities, allowing administrators to control user accounts and permissions. This enables the organization to restrict or remove access for users who consistently contribute inappropriate or illegal content.

protectionFromHarassment.harassmentPolicy:
The Ushahidi Platform is age-agnostic. This means that persons of all age groups can access both the platform's frontend and backend features. Our community advocacy and technology privacy teams regularly review and monitor the new and existing deployments created on our servers for predatory threats such as bullying, grooming, abuse, and aggression. 

Every two weeks, Ushahidi team members randomly spot-check deployments, and this enables us to further check the thematic areas and content of deployments that we host. We also partner with digital security organizations such as Tor in order to amplify safeguarding information, advice, and guidance for deployers and users of Ushahidi. 

Every visitor or user of any hosted Ushahidi deployment has 24/7 access to our community support channel, which they can use to anonymously report any content that poses a risk to the safety and security of underage users. After receiving the report, our community advocacy and technology privacy teams will suspend the deployment and form a committee to investigate the claims quickly. Any deployments whose content is found in contravention shall be banned indefinitely. Over the last 15 years of our existence, Ushahidi has not discovered or received any complaint of a deployment that poses a risk to its underage users or visitors.  

Code of conduct - https://docs.ushahidi.com/platform-developer-documentation/code-of-conduct
